G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (actions for modification of custody and child support orders) and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court issued the original custody order on March 15, 2018.

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with the best interests of the child, as defined in G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and interpreted by the courts in cases including Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000), and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and interprets G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) (and by analogy the same best‑interests framework as under G.L. c. 208, § 28), reiterating that custody and modification decisions must be based on the child’s best interests and that the judge may weigh any pertinent factors to determine which arrangement best serves those interests. The court affirms the Probate Court’s exercise of discretion in awarding custody based on a holistic best‑interests analysis, making Custody of Zia appropriate authority for the general proposition that the requested modification must be consistent with the child’s best interests as defined in those statutes and interpreted by the courts.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute. … ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child[] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ … ‘The decision of which parent will promote a child's best interests ‘is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’’”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with the best interests of the child, as defined in G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and interpreted by the courts in cases including Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000), and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the “best interests of the child” standard as defined in Massachusetts statutes and interpreted in, among others, Yannas. In this opinion, the SJC explicitly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30’s “upon cause shown” language to mean removal must be in the child’s best interests, and then articulates the substantive best‑interests analysis, including how the custodial parent’s well‑being and the child’s relationship with the noncustodial parent factor into that inquiry. That best‑interests framework is what later cases, such as Custody of Zia, cite and build upon, so this decision supports the proposition that a requested modification must be consistent with the child’s best interests as so interpreted.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30…provides that…[a child] shall not…be removed out of this commonwealth…unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… [and] the possible adverse effect of the…curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent….”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: In determining whether a modification is warranted, Massachusetts courts consider both the change in parental circumstances and the child’s welfare.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification standard case, and it applies a pure ‘best interests of the child’ analysis. While the opinion notes that relocation can be a substantial change in circumstances (quoting the ALI Principles), the court does not frame its analysis as jointly considering parental changed circumstances and child welfare as co‑factors in deciding whether a ‘modification’ is warranted. Instead, it focuses on whether removal is in the children’s best interests, largely independent of the relocating parent’s circumstances, so it does not establish the proposition as stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)…state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances…only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising…’ … ‘(4)…the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests…including the effects of the relocation on the child.’ … We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order…[based on] the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move.”

Miller v. Miller, 478 Mass. 642 (2018).proposition: In determining whether a modification is warranted, Massachusetts courts consider both the change in parental circumstances and the child’s welfare.

Care and Protection of Erin, 443 Mass. 5.raw_text: Care and Protection of Erin, 443 Mass. 567 (2005)
Care and Protection of Erin, 443 Mass. 5.proposition: A parent’s increased stability, improved housing, and greater ability to provide care may constitute a material change.
Care and Protection of Erin, 443 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss what is required on a petition for review and redetermination, and states that the moving party must show changed circumstances since the initial determination. However, it does not identify or hold that a parent’s increased stability, improved housing, or greater ability to provide care constitute a material change; those facts appear only as background about the mother’s situation and are not analyzed as sufficient or insufficient changes. Thus, the case sets the general ‘change in circumstances’ standard but does not specifically support the more detailed proposition stated.
Care and Protection of Erin, 443 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “The party filing the petition must present some credible evidence that circumstances have changed since the initial determination such that the child may no longer be in need of care and protection. Once the party filing the petition meets its burden of production, the department must make its showing.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: A parent’s increased stability, improved housing, and greater ability to provide care may constitute a material change.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde concerns the initial divorce, custody, property division, and visitation determinations after trial, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. The court does not discuss what constitutes a ‘material change’ in circumstances or analyze improved stability, housing, or caregiving capacity as a basis for modifying an existing custody or support order. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a parent’s increased stability, improved housing, and greater ability to provide care may constitute a material change.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: In deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare... The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.proposition: The emotional well-being and expressed wishes of the child are highly relevant to the best‑interest analysis.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the governing standard as parental unfitness and the State’s ability to intervene when parents cannot provide basic care, not as an open-ended ‘best‑interest’ inquiry that gives special weight to the child’s emotional well‑being or expressed wishes. The child here is a newborn, so there is no discussion of the child’s preferences, and the reasoning focuses on neglect, prognostic evidence, and procedural protections (specific findings, standard of proof). Thus, the case does not support the proposition that the child’s emotional well‑being and expressed wishes are highly relevant factors in the best‑interest analysis.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: Pursuant to the statutory provision creating the action, G. L. c. 119, § 24 … any person concerned for a child’s welfare may file a petition … alleging that the child ‘is without necessary and proper physical, educational or moral care and discipline, or is growing up under conditions or circumstances damaging to a child’s sound character development….’ If the court finds the allegations proved, the judge may commit the child to the department … or … make any other order deemed appropriate to the child’s best interests. … [T]he Commonwealth may not attempt to force the breakup of a natural family without an affirmative showing of parental unfitness.

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The emotional well-being and expressed wishes of the child are highly relevant to the best‑interest analysis.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the custody and visitation analysis around the child’s best interests and repeatedly emphasizes the child’s emotional harm, emotional needs, and the impact of the father’s conduct on the child’s emotional well-being and relationship with the mother. It also notes that the judge must consider whether living conditions adversely affect the child’s emotional health and, in the removal discussion, lists the effect on the child’s emotional needs as a key factor. Although the child’s own wishes are not heavily featured, the case clearly treats the child’s emotional well-being as highly relevant to the best‑interest analysis.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In making a decision about legal or physical custody, a judge ‘shall consider whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31… Additionally, in abuse prevention proceedings, ‘[i]f ordering visitation to the abusive parent, the court shall provide for the safety and well-being of the child and the safety of the abused parent.’… [T]he judge explained that, due to the father’s chronic misbehavior, any contact during at least a period of one year between the father and the child will cause the child to suffer serious emotional harm.”}

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The Court must ensure that the child’s developmental and emotional needs are served by frequent and meaningful contact with both parents.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the overarching principle that the child’s welfare is the paramount consideration in custody decisions, and it affirms a decree granting custody to the father and stepmother with no visitation rights for the mother. It does not state that the court must ensure frequent and meaningful contact with both parents; in fact, it upholds a complete denial of visitation where that was found to be in the child’s best interests. The proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the court’s holding.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The material facts found and reported by the judge support his action in awarding custody of the child to the father and stepmother with no rights of visitation by the mother. In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. …’ We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Court must ensure that the child’s developmental and emotional needs are served by frequent and meaningful contact with both parents.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the broad ‘best interests of the child’ standard and weighs stability, bonding, sibling relationships, and the child’s developmental needs, but it does not articulate any rule that the court must ensure frequent and meaningful contact with both parents. In fact, both biological parents have been found unfit, and the decision is between two nonparent adoptive placements, with no requirement or emphasis on maintaining contact with each parent. The case therefore does not establish or affirm the specific legal principle stated in the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs….”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: When a noncustodial parent demonstrates improved parenting capacity and stability, expansion of parenting time is warranted.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenberg v. Merida deals with child support (including credit for SSDI dependency benefits), attachment of assets, and modification of legal custody from shared to sole custody. It does not address expansion of parenting time/visitation for a noncustodial parent based on improved parenting capacity or stability. The only custody-related holding vacates a change to sole legal custody due to insufficient findings; there is no discussion about increasing parenting time as requested in the proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, the judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings…’ We thus cannot determine what factors the judge considered in making the custody award, and we accordingly cannot sustain the award.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: When a noncustodial parent demonstrates improved parenting capacity and stability, expansion of parenting time is warranted.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is about selecting an initial custodial arrangement under the best-interests standard and the statutory factors in G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a). It does not discuss a noncustodial parent later demonstrating improved parenting capacity or stability, nor does it state that such an improvement warrants expansion of parenting time. Instead, the court emphasizes preserving satisfactory existing arrangements and stability, and it affirms a custody order crafted from a comparative assessment of two currently fit parents, not from changed circumstances of a noncustodial parent.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child."
